text: They had this machine. They had two machines, really. One of them slid down into your stomach like a black cobra down an echoing well looking for all the old water and the old time gathered there. It drank up the green matter that flowed to the top in a slow boil. Did it drink of the darkness? Did it suck out all the poisons accumulated with the years? It fed in silence with an occasional sound of inner suffocation and blind searching. It had an Eye. The impersonal operator of the machine could, by wearing a special optical helmet, gaze into the soul of the person whom he was pumping out. What did the Eye see? He did not say. He saw but did not see what the Eye saw. The entire operation was not unlike the digging of a trench in ones yard. The woman on the bed was no more than a hard stratum of marble they had reached. Go on, anyway, shove the bore down, slush up the emptiness, if such a thing could be brought out in the throb of the suction snake. The operator stood smoking a cigarette. The other machine was working, too.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The other machine, operated by an equally impersonal fellow in nonstainable reddish-brown coveralls. This machine pumped all of the blood from the body and replaced it with fresh blood and serum.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Got to clean em out both ways,ù said the operator, standing over the silent woman. No use getting the stomach if you dont clean the blood. Leave that stuff in the blood and the blood hits the brain like a mallet, bang, a couple thousand times and the brain just gives up, just quits.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Stop it!ù said Montag.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I was just sayin,ù said the operator.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Are you done?ù said Montag.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: They shut the machines up tight. Were done.ù His anger did not even touch them. They stood with the cigarette smoke curling around their noses and into their eyes without making them blink or squint. Thats fifty bucks.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: First, why dont you tell me if shell be all right?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Sure, shell be okay. We got all the mean stuff right in our suitcase here, it cant get at her now. As I said, you take out the old and put in the new and youre okay.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Neither of you is an M.D. Why didnt they send an M.D. from Emergency?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Hell!ù The operators cigarette moved on his lip. We get these cases nine or ten a night. Got so many, starting a few years ago, we had the special machines built. With the optical lens, of course, that was new; the rest is ancient. You dont need an M.D., case like this; all you need is two handymen, clean up the problem in half an hour. Lookùîhe started for the doorîwe gotta go. Just had another call on the old ear-thimble. Ten blocks from here. Someone else just jumped off the cap of a pillbox. Call if you need us again. Keep her quiet. We got a contrasedative in her. Shell wake up hungry. So long.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: And the men with the cigarettes in their straight-lined mouths, the men with the eyes of puff adders, took up their load of machine and tube, their case of liquid melancholy and the slow dark sludge of nameless stuff, and strolled out the door.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag sank down into a chair and looked at this woman. Her eyes were closed now, gently, and he put out his hand to feel the warmness of breath on his palm.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Mildred,ù he said, at last.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: There are too many of us, he thought. There are billions of us and thats too many. Nobody knows anyone. Strangers come and violate you. Strangers come and cut your heart out. Strangers come and take your blood. Good God, who were those men? I never saw them before in my life!
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Half an hour passed.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The bloodstream in this woman was new and it seemed to have done a new thing to her. Her cheeks were very pink and her lips were very fresh and full of color and they looked soft and relaxed. Someone elses blood there. If only someone elses flesh and brain and memory. If only they could have taken her mind along to the dry cleaners and emptied the pockets and steamed and cleansed it and reblocked it and brought it back in the morning. If only . . .
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He got up and put back the drapes and opened the windows wide to let the night air in. It was two oclock in the morning. Was it only an hour ago, Clarisse McClellan in the street, and him coming in, and the dark room and his foot kicking the little crystal bottle? Only an hour, but the word had melted down and sprung up in a new and colorless form.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Laughter blew across the moon-colored lawn from the house of Clarisse and her father and mother and the uncle who smiled so quietly and so earnestly. Above all, their laughter was relaxed and hearty and not forced in any way, coming from the house that was so brightly lit this late at night while all the other houses were kept to themselves in darkness. Montag heard the voices talking, talking, talking, giving, talking, weaving, reweaving their hypnotic web.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag moved out through the French windows and crossed the lawn, without even thinking of it. He stood outside the talking house in the shadows, thinking he might even tap on their door and whisper, Let me come in. I wont say anything. I just want to listen. What is it youre saying?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: But instead he stood there, very cold, his face a mask of ice, listening to a mans voice (the uncle?) moving along at an easy pace:
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Well, after all, this is the age of the disposable tissue. Blow your nose on a person, wad them, flush them away, reach for another, blow, wad, flush. Everyone using everyone elses coattails. How are you supposed to root for the home team when you dont even have a program or know the names? For that matter, what color jerseys are they wearing as they trot out on the field?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag moved back to his own house, left the window wide, checked Mildred, tucked the covers about her carefully, and then lay down with the moonlight on his cheekbones and on the frowning ridges in his brow, with the moonlight distilled in each eye to form a silver cataract there.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: One drop of rain. Clarisse. Another drop. Mildred. A third. The uncle. A fourth. The fire tonight. One, Clarisse. Two, Mildred. Three, uncle. Four, fire. One, Mildred, two, Clarisse. One, two, three, four, five, Clarisse, Mildred, uncle, fire, sleeping tablets, men, disposable tissue, coattails, blow, wad, flush, Clarisse, Mildred, uncle, fire, tablets, tissues, blow, wad, flush. One, two, three, one, two, three! Rain. The storm. The uncle laughing. Thunder falling downstairs. The whole world pouring down. The fire gushing up in a volcano. All rushing on down around in a spouting roar and rivering stream toward morning.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I dont know anything anymore,ù he said, and let a sleep lozenge dissolve on his tongue.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: At nine in the morning, Mildreds bed was empty.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag got up quickly, his heart pumping, and ran down the hall and stopped at the kitchen door.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Toast popped out of the silver toaster, was seized by a spidery metal hand that drenched it with melted butter.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Mildred watched the toast delivered to her plate. She had both ears plugged with electronic bees that were humming the hour away. She looked up suddenly, saw him and nodded.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: You all right?ù he asked.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She was an expert at lip reading from ten years of apprenticeship at Seashell ear-thimbles. She nodded again. She set the toaster clicking away at another piece of bread.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag sat down.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: His wife said, I dont know why I should be so hungry.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Youîù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Im hungry.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Last night,ù he began.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Didnt sleep well. Feel terrible,ù she said. God, Im hungry. I cant figure it.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Last nightîù he said again.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She watched his lips casually. What about last night?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Dont you remember?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: What? Did we have a wild party or something? Feel like Ive a hangover. God, Im hungry. Who was here?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: A few people,ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Thats what I thought.ù She chewed her toast. Sore stomach, but Im hungry as all get-out. Hope I didnt do anything foolish at the party.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: No,ù he said, quietly.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The toaster spidered out a piece of buttered bread for him. He held it in his hand, feeling obligated.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: You dont look so hot yourself,ù said his wife.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: In the late afternoon it rained and the entire world was dark gray. He stood in the hall of his house, putting on his badge with the orange salamander burning across it. He stood looking up at the air-conditioning vent in the hall for a long time. His wife in the TV parlor paused long enough from reading her script to glance up. Hey,ù she said. The mans thinking!ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Yes,ù he said. I wanted to talk to you.ù He paused. You took all the pills in your bottle last night.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Oh, I wouldnt do that,ù she said, surprised.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The bottle was empty.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I wouldnt do a thing like that. Why would I do a thing like that?ù she said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Maybe you took two pills and forgot and took two more, and forgot again and took two more, and were so dopey you kept right on until you had thirty or forty of them in you.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Heck,ù she said, what would I want to go and do a silly thing like that for?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I dont know,ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She was quite obviously waiting for him to go. I didnt do that,ù she said. Never in a billion years.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: All right if you say so,ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Thats what the lady said.ù She turned back to her script.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Whats on this afternoon?ù he asked, tiredly.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She didnt look up from the script again. Well, this is a play comes on the wall-to-wall circuit in ten minutes. They mailed me my part this morning. I sent in some box tops. They write the script with one part missing. Its a new idea. The homemaker, thats me, is the missing part. When it comes time for the missing lines, they all look at me out of the three walls and I say the lines. Here, for instance, the man says, òWhat do you think of this whole idea, Helen? And he looks at me sitting here center stage, see? And I say, I sayîù She paused and ran her finger under a line on the script.  òI think thats fine! And then they go on with the play until he says, òDo you agree to that, Helen? and I say, òI sure do! Isnt that fun, Guy?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He stood in the hall looking at her.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Its sure fun,ù she said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Whats the play about?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I just told you. There are these people named Bob and Ruth and Helen.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Oh.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Its really fun. Itll be even more fun when we can afford to have the fourth wall installed. How long you figure before we save up and get the fourth wall torn out and a fourth wall-TV put in? Its only two thousand dollars.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Thats one-third of my yearly pay.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Its only two thousand dollars,ù she replied. And I should think youd consider me sometimes. If we had a fourth wall, why itd be just like this room wasnt ours at all, but all kinds of exotic peoples rooms. We could do without a few things.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Were already doing without a few things to pay for the third wall. It was put in only two months ago, remember?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Is that all it was?ù She sat looking at him for a long moment. Well, goodbye, dear.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Goodbye,ù he said. He stopped and turned around. Does it have a happy ending?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I havent read that far.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He walked over, read the last page, nodded, folded the script, and handed it back to her. He walked out of the house into the rain.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The rain was thinning away and the girl was walking in the center of the sidewalk with her head up and the few drops falling on her face. She smiled when she saw Montag.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Hello!ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He said hello and then said, What are you up to now?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Im still crazy. The rain feels good. I love to walk in it.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I dont think Id like that,ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: You might if you tried.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I never have.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She licked her lips. Rain even tastes good.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: What do you do, go around trying everything once?ù he asked.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Sometimes twice.ù She looked at something in her hand.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Whatve you got there?ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I guess its the last of the dandelions this year. I didnt think Id find one on the lawn this late. Have you ever heard of rubbing it under your chin? Look.ù She touched her chin with the flower, laughing.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Why?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: If it rubs off, it means Im in love. Has it?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He could hardly do anything else but look.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Well?ù she said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Youre yellow under there.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Fine! Lets try you now.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: It wont work for me.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Here.ù Before he could move she had put the dandelion under his chin. He drew back and she laughed. Hold still!ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: She peered under his chin and frowned.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Well?ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: What a shame,ù she said. Youre not in love with anyone.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Yes, I am!ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: It doesnt show.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I am, very much in love!ù He tried to conjure up a face to fit the words, but there was no face. I am!ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Oh, please dont look that way.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Its that dandelion,ù he said. Youve used it all up on yourself. Thats why it wont work for me.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Of course, that must be it. Oh now Ive upset you, I can see I have; Im sorry, really I am.ù She touched his elbow.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: No, no,ù he said, quickly, Im all right.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Ive got to be going, so say you forgive me, I dont want you angry with me.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Im not angry. Upset, yes.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Ive got to go see my psychiatrist now. They make me go. I make up things to say. I dont know what he thinks of me. He says Im a regular onion! I keep him busy peeling away the layers.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Im inclined to believe you need the psychiatrist,ù said Montag.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: You dont mean that.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He took a breath and let it out and at last said, No, I dont mean that.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The psychiatrist wants to know why I go out and hike around in the forests and watch the birds and collect butterflies. Ill show you my collection some day.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Good.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: They want to know what I do with all my time. I tell them that sometimes I just sit and think. But I wont tell them what. Ive got them running. And sometimes, I tell them, I like to put my head back, like this, and let the rain fall in my mouth. It tastes just like wine. Have you ever tried it?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: No, Iîù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: You have forgiven me, havent you?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Yes.ù He thought about it. Yes, I have. God knows why. Youre peculiar, youre aggravating, yet youre easy to forgive. You say youre seventeen?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Wellînext month.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: How odd. How strange. And my wife thirty and yet you seem so much older at times. I cant get over it.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Youre peculiar yourself, Mr. Montag. Sometimes I even forget youre a fireman. Now, may I make you angry again?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Go ahead.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: How did it start? How did you get into it? How did you pick your work and how did you happen to think to take the job you have? Youre not like the others. Ive seen a few; I know. When I talk, you look at me. When I said something about the moon, you looked at the moon, last night. The others would never do that. The others would walk off and leave me talking. Or threaten me. No one has time any more for anyone else. Youre one of the few who put up with me. Thats why I think its so strange youre a fireman, it just doesnt seem right for you, somehow.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He felt his body divide itself into a hotness and a coldness, a softness and a hardness, a trembling and a not trembling, the two halves grinding one upon the other.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Youd better run on to your appointment,ù he said.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: And she ran off and left him standing there in the rain. Only after a long time did he move.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: And then, very slowly, as he walked, he tilted his head back in the rain, for just a few moments, and opened his mouth. . . .
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The Mechanical Hound slept but did not sleep, lived but did not live in its gently humming, gently vibrating, softly illuminated kennel back in a dark corner of the firehouse. The dim light of one in the morning, the moonlight from the open sky framed through the great window, touched here and there on the brass and the copper and the steel of the faintly trembling beast. Light flickered on bits of ruby glass and on sensitive capillary hairs in the nylonbrushed nostrils of the creature that quivered gently, gently, its eight legs spidered under it on rubber-padded paws.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag slid down the brass pole. He went out to look at the city and the clouds had cleared away completely, and he lit a cigarette and came back to bend down and look at the Hound. It was like a great bee come home from some field where the honey is full of poison wildness, of insanity and nightmare, its body crammed with that over-rich nectar and now it was sleeping the evil out of itself.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Hello,ù whispered Montag, fascinated as always with the dead beast, the living beast.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Nights when things got dull, which was every night, the men slid down the brass poles, and set the ticking combinations of the olfactory system of the Hound and let loose rats in the firehouse areaway, and sometimes chickens, and sometimes cats that would have to be drowned anyway, and there would be betting to see which of the cats or chickens or rats the Hound would seize first. The animals were turned loose. Three seconds later the game was done, the rat, cat, or chicken caught half across the areaway, gripped in gentling paws while a four-inch hollow steel needle plunged down from the proboscis of the Hound to inject massive jolts of morphine or procaine. The pawn was then tossed in the incinerator. A new game began.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag stayed upstairs most nights when this went on. There had been a time two years ago when he had bet with the best of them, and lost a weeks salary and faced Mildreds insane anger, which showed itself in veins and blotches. But now nights he lay in his bunk, face turned to the wall, listening to the whoops of laughter below and the pianostring scurry of rat feet, the violin squeaking of mice, and the great shadowing, motioned silence of the Hound leaping out like a moth in the raw light, finding, holding its victim, inserting needle and going back to its kennel to die as if a switch had been turned.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag touched the muzzle.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The Hound growled.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag jumped back.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The Hound half rose in its kennel and looked at him with green-blue neon light flickering in its suddenly activated eye bulbs. It growled again, a strange rasping combination of electrical sizzle, a frying sound, a scraping of metal, a turning of cogs that seemed rusty and ancient with suspicion.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: No, no, boy,ù said Montag, his heart pounding.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: He saw the silver needle extend upon the air an inch, pull back, extend, pull back. The growl simmered in the beast and it looked at him.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag backed up. The Hound took a step from its kennel. Montag grabbed the brass pole with one hand. The pole, reacting, slid upward, and took him through the ceiling, quietly. He stepped off in the half-lit deck of the upper level. He was trembling and his face was green-white. Below, the Hound had sunk back down upon its eight incredible insect legs and was humming to itself again, its multifaceted eyes at peace.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag stood, letting the fears pass, by the drop-hole. Behind him, four men at a card table under a greenlidded light in the corner glanced briefly but said nothing. Only the man with the Captains hat and the sign of the Phoenix on his hat, at last, curious, his playing cards in his thin hand, talked across the long room.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag . . . ?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: It doesnt like me,ù said Montag.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: What, the Hound?ù The Captain studied his cards. Come off it. It doesnt like or dislike. It just òfunctions. Its like a lesson in ballistics. It has a trajectory we decide on for it. It follows through. It targets itself, homes itself, and cuts off. Its only copper wire, storage batteries, and electricity.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Montag swallowed. Its calculators can be set to any combination, so many amino acids, so much sulphur, so much butterfat and alkaline. Right?ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: We know all that.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: All of those chemical balances and percentages on all of us here in the house are recorded in the master file downstairs. It would be easy for someone to set up a partial combination on the Hounds òmemory, a touch of amino acids, perhaps. That would account for what the animal did just now. Reacted toward me.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Hell,ù said the Captain.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Irritated, but not completely angry. Just enough òmemory set up in it by someone so it growled when I touched it.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Who would do a thing like that?ù asked the Captain. You havent any enemies here, Guy.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: None that I know of.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Well have the Hound checked by our technicians tomorrow.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: This isnt the first time its threatened me,ù said Montag. Last month it happened twice.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: Well fix it up. Dont worry.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: But Montag did not move and only stood thinking of the ventilator grill in the hall at home and what lay hidden behind the grill. If someone here in the firehouse knew about the ventilator then mightnt they tellù the Hound . . . ?
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: The Captain came over to the drop hole and gave Montag a questioning glance.
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: I was just figuring,ù said Montag, what does the Hound think about down there nights? Is it coming alive on us, really? It makes me cold.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray

text: It doesnt think anything we dont want it to think.ù
title: Fahrenheit 451

He could feel the poison working up his wrists and into his elbows and his shoulders, and then the jump-over from shoulder blade to shoulder blade like a spark leaping a gap. His hands were ravenous. And me not sleeping tonight or tomorrow night or any night for a long while, now that this has started. And he thought of her lying on the bed with the two technicians standing straight over her, not bent with concern, but only standing straight, arms folded. And he remembered thinking then that if she died, he was certain he wouldnt cry. For it would be the dying of an unknown, a street face, a newspaper image, and it was suddenly so very wrong that he had begun to cry, not at death but at the thought of not crying at death, a silly empty man near a silly empty woman, while the hungry snake made her still more empty.

text: Well, wasnt there a wall between him and Mildred, when you came down to it? Literally not just one wall but, so far, three! And expensive, too! Hows Uncle Louis today?ù Who?ù And Aunt Maude?ù The most significant memory he had of Mildred, really, was of a little girl in a forest without trees (how odd!) or rather a little girl lost on a plateau where there used to be trees (you could feel the memory of their shapes all about) sitting in the center of the living room.ù The living room; what a good job of labeling that was now.
